title: Quiz 4: Neuro & Physical Assessment
description: Test your understanding of neurological observations, vital signs, and physical exam techniques.

questions.question: Which of the following are components of a neurological observation/assessment? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Neuro obs focus on consciousness (AVPU/GCS), pupils (size/reaction), and motor/sensory function.

questions.question: Arrange the steps of assessing Level of Consciousness in the correct sequence:
questions.explanation: Voice -> Command -> Pain. Always start with the least intrusive stimulus.

questions.question: The four fundamental techniques of physical examination are Inspection, Palpation, ___BLANK___, and Auscultation.
When checking pupils, what does a 'sluggish' reaction indicate?

options.text: The pupil constricts slowly to light
The pupil does not change size
The pupil dilates instead of constricts

questions.explanation: Sluggish means the reaction is present but slower than normal. 'Fixed' means no reaction.

questions.question: Match the reflex with the testing site:
questions.explanation: Biceps/Triceps are arm reflexes; Patellar is knee; Achilles is ankle.

questions.question: When examining the abdomen, Auscultation should be performed BEFORE Palpation.
questions.explanation: For the abdomen, look then listen. Palpation and percussion can alter bowel sounds, so they are done after auscultation.
questions.hint: Touching might stir up the bowels.

questions.question: Which sign is elicited by flexing the hip to 90 degrees and then extending the knee, causing pain/resistance?
questions.explanation: Kernig's sign indicates meningeal irritation. Brudzinski's involves neck flexion.

questions.question: What is the term for the 'drum-like' sound produced by percussing an air-filled stomach?
questions.explanation: Tympani is the drum-like sound heard over air-filled viscus like the stomach.

questions.question: A frequency of observation (e.g., 1/4 hourly) means you check the patient every 4 hours.
questions.explanation: 1/4 hourly means every 15 minutes (quarter of an hour). Every 4 hours would be 4-hourly.

questions.question: To test for 'tactile fremitus', what should you ask the patient to do?
questions.explanation: Tactile fremitus is the vibration felt on the chest wall when the patient speaks.
